Award.AwardTitle: Oceanographic Technical Services, R/V Thompson and R/V Barnes, 2012-2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
University of Washington proposes to support technical services on R/V Thompson, a 274? general purpose, global class research vessel, and R/V Barnes, a 66-foot coastal research vessel, both operated as part of the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System research fleet. The proposal requests support for basic services. They will provide at least two shipboard technicians on each cruise of R/V Thompson to support seagoing research projects and to maintain, calibrate and provide for qualified users items from their pool of shared-use research instrumentation. As part of the basic services, they will maintain and operate the multibeam sonar systems on R/V Thompson. For R/V Barnes, a technician is available to sail if desired by the chief scientists, though (s)he will often not sail due to space limitations. The technician will provide shared-use instrumentation for use by the scientists, and provide remote support as needed if a technician does not sail. The budget included with this proposal is for the first year of a 5-year continuing grant.

Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under criterion two, providing infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The support of maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

SHIPBOARD SCIENCE SUPPORT 2012 – 2017

R/V Thomas G. Thompson and R/V Clifford A. Barnes

NSF Ocean Technical Services Award OCE-1228287

 

 

Intellectual Merit:

This proposal and award provided funding for the University of Washington’s Shipboard Science Support Group, SSSG, to provide technical and scientific support for research and educational cruises aboard the two ships operated by the University of Washington, School of Oceanography Marine Operations Department, the R/V Clifford A. Barnes and the R/V Thomas G. Thompson. The SSSG supports general deck work for science operations, computer and network management, maintenance and repair of electronic instrumentation and general purpose sampling equipment.  The University of Washington remains committed to managing and maintaining these facilities in order to provide first-rate service in a safe, cost-effective, and environmentally responsible manner.

 

The Shipboard Science Support Group plays an essential role in facilitating scientists’ and educators’ fullest utilization of these platforms and tools. A core component of our mission, as an institution of higher learning, is the provision of educational opportunities both to students in the earth and ocean sciences and to teachers nationwide through ongoing programs wherein opportunities are provided for educators to join and participate in sea-going research expeditions, later sharing those experiences with their K through 12th grade students.  The University of Washington, with the support of the National Science Foundation and with coordination by the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS), remains dedicated to and focused upon the national endeavor to understand the physical, chemical, geological and biological processes of the world ocean.

 

 

CY 2012-CY 2017 Services Provided

 

During the six years of funding provided under this award, the Shipboard Science Support Group provided services in support of 80 cruises (513 NSF-funded days, 1660 total funded days) aboard the R/V Thomas G. Thompson and 138 cruises (287 NSF-funded days, 498 total funded days) aboard the R/V Clifford A. Barnes.

 

The Thompson worked throughout the Pacific Ocean, focused in the eastern part of the Pacific between Chile and Washington State, and into Puget Sound.  Studies included such diverse activities as bathymetric mapping of the seafloor, geochemistry, coring, biological productivity and specimen collections, measurement of currents, ocean-atmosphere interactions and gas exchange, instrument placement and underwater photography and video recording near hydrothermally-active sites, ocean bottom seismometer and mooring deployments and recovery, support for use of remotely operated vehicles (JASON and ROPOS), and student instruction and research opportunities.

 

The Barnes worked in Puget Sound and the waters around Vancouver Island during these years.  Activities included characterization of the water column hydrography, near-bottom currents, microbial biogeochemical activity, and sediment transport near a river mouth, as well as student instruction and research activities.

 

Contributions within Discipline:

 

Provision of these sea-going research and educational facilities enabled marine scientists and investigators from the University of Washington and other institutions nationwide to study natural phenomena, and to instruct the future scientists and stewards of our marine ecosystems while they are embarked aboard state-of-the-art oceanographic research vessels that are well equipped with laboratories, sensors, analytical equipment, communications links to shore-side scientists and educators, and computational and data processing systems.

 

Student educational cruises are conducted on both vessels. These cruises allow students the opportunity to take classroom instruction out into field research problems with real-world phenomena. Students are given an opportunity to utilize state-of-the-art instrumentation, operated and maintained by the U.W. SSSG, as they study, experiment and report on ocean processes.

Additionally, during the shipyard period for the Thompson midlife refit, six of our technicians sailed aboard other vessels operated by UNOLS institutions in support of NSF-funded and other research to assist those institutions in fulfilling their staffing needs; this allowed each organization to exchange ideas and be exposed to alternative procedures for carrying out our science missions.

 

R/V Thomas G. Thompson:

Utilizing other funds from annual Ocean Instrumentation awards during this six year interval, our personnel made numerous upgrades to the computers and network functions for data collection and archiving aboard the Thompson.  We also replaced the aging fume hoods on the Thompson. We have upgraded our meteorological sensors and data acquisition computers and software.  We have been implementing changes to our procedures and machinery to comply with recent UNOLS safety standards.  Many of these improvements were accomplished during our midlife refit shipyard period when all of our personnel spent considerable time together at the shipyard to participate in rewiring, replacement, and renovations of our science systems.  

 

R/V Clifford A. Barnes:

During this period, we upgraded our computers and data archiving systems on the Barnes and added new met sensors to improve our meteorological data collection on board.  The end of 2017 also marked the last full year of science cruises on the Barnes.  In early 2018, the new replacement coastal vessel, R/V Rachel Carson, began to conduct research cruises in Puget Sound.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/29/2018
Modified by: Doug G Russell
